0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Bleeding; Prophylaxis - Hereditary factor XIII A subunit deficiency: 35 international units/kg slow IV bolus (not to exceed 1 to 2 mL/minute) once monthly; consider dose adjustment if target trough levels of factor XIII activity of 10% or more are not reached

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Bleeding; Prophylaxis - Hereditary factor XIII A subunit deficiency: 35 international units/kg slow IV bolus (not to exceed 1 to 2 mL/minute) once monthly; consider dose adjustment if target trough levels of factor XIII activity of 10% or more are not reached

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Bleeding; Prophylaxis - Hereditary factor XIII A subunit deficiency

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to recombinant coagulation factor XIII or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, including anaphylactic reactions, may occur; discontinue use immediately if suspected
  • inhibitory antibodies may develop; if inhibitors are suspected with a lack of therapeutic response (evidenced by bleeding or lab findings of factor XIII activity that does not reach expected levels), test for antibodies
  • pediatric patients; adverse events were reported more frequently than in adults
  • thromboembolism may occur; monitoring recommended for those with predisposition for thrombosis
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (1% or greater)
  • Hematologic:Elevated D-dimer level (1% or greater)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development, Non-neutralizing (5.2%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Pain in limb (1% or greater)
  • Neurologic:Headache (1% or greater)
Serious
Immunologic:Anaphylaxis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Recombinant coagulation factor XIII A-subunit is a recombinant human factor XIII-A(2) homodimer composed of 2 factor XIII A-subunits. Recombinant coagulation factor XIII A-subunit binds to free human factor XIII B-subunit and is activated by thrombin in the presence of calcium; once active, it increases the mechanical strength of fibrin clots, retards fibrinolysis, and enhances platelet adhesion to the site of injury in a dose-dependent manner.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • bring powder and provided diluent to a temperature of not more than 25 degrees C (77 degrees F)
  • reconstitute powder with provided diluent and gently swirl until powder is dissolved; do not aim stream of diluent directly at powder and do not shake vial
  • reconstituted solution may be diluted further with 0.9% sodium chloride for administration of small doses
  • may be stored refrigerated or at room temperature for up to 3 hours
  • administer as a slow bolus IV injection at a rate not exceeding 1 to 2 mL/minute; do not give as an IV drip

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• trough factor XIII activity levels, using a validated assay, to obtain an activity level of 10% or higher
  • fewer bleeding episodes may indicate clinical efficacy
  • factor XIII inhibitory antibody concentration assay, in patients with lower than expected plasma activity levels or uncontrolled bleeding
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis, in patients with conditions that predispose them to thrombosis

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Side effects may include headache, pain in the extremities, and injection site pain.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of anaphylaxis or hypersensitivity reactions (urticaria, rash, tightness of chest, wheezing, hypotension).
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of thrombosis (eg, limb or abdomen swelling and/or pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, loss of sensation or motor power, altered consciousness, vision, or speech).
  • Tell patient to report breakthrough bleeding.
